author: hrad69
body: Sometimes I think people here don't think about the company behind the ticker. "AMD can't possibly go any higher!!!" bears say. Have you used AMD processors lately? Are you a PC enthusiast? Have you read up on the differences between 5nm, 7nm, and 10nm processors? Honestly, you don't need to be a computer expert. They are *way* ahead, and intel is the only competition. You can buy an AMD processor that produces lower temps, nearly equivalent frame rates in-game, running at lower clock speeds, and is cheaper than Intel at nearly every price point. Plus, their core-counts make them better for workplace environments (adobe suite, video editing, rendering, etc). The only area Intel wins is in certain game frame rates, and it's a teeny tiny difference that is shrinking as games utilize more cores. Plus they still pale in comparison in terms of temps. Heck, AMD's integrated graphics are even decent. They are in *both* major console releases coming up. You're welcome to watch AMD's meteoric rise to 100+ from the sidelines if you like.

author: RdyPdy
body: I worked for DocuSign for 2.5 years. While it is the most expensive in its class it definitely is not the shittiest. All the other competitors are garbage. The only real competition is a tool adobe purchased for shits and giggles and hardly supports. While the concept is simple there is a lot more that goes into esignature than a line on a page. Availability and security are highly valuable in this space. Customers also love the ease of use from a workflow perspective. While I think $38 B is overvalued at the moment do you really think we’ll go back to physically signing contracts in the next 15-20 years?

author: WallStreetHelpBot
body:
It's not but I would also say it is a bit to soon to see how this will turn out but it absolutely could be massive and easily shoot up their price. 

While most general analyst don't likely understand, there is still the core thing to see how well Apple wrangles in it's developers to release all software on it moving forward within their App Store ecosystem and oh boy if they pull that off then they have even more of a market they will squeeze their 30% of even more.

While their will technically be support for older x86 applications just look at Windows/Linux arm for the range of shit show emulation for that can go and Apple isn't making any guarantees it will be better, just that it will "work" and it will be part of the transition. The "ultimate" goal is for almost all software on the Mac to essentially go through the Apple Store also and have similar policy like the app store. I.E Image Apple also taking a 30% cut of Office, Adobe, and so on.

Apple Silicon is only part of the play, the other part is that Apple Silicon cements you "NEED" to use the latest version of MacOS for it and use the latest Xcode to make apps for it which means they can tunnel even more through their app store.

author: The-Hyrax
body:
Less chasing more planning. I know a bunch here doesn't believe in TA and although it isn't perfect, it helped me to spot trends and set-ups for potential breakouts. Played AMZN, AAPL, TSLA (only once, unfortunately), CHWY, PYPL, ADBE, NVDA, NFLX, SQ, SE, FB, SLV, GLD, ETSY

I still need to learn to trade less emotional. E.g. I won but also lost on AMZN. When I lost on AMZN, I told myself 'when AMZN drops back below 3,200 and can't go back above, I'm closing' - next thing I know I kept holding until like 3,150. Lost three times as much this way. 

Another lesson I learned after bagholding: I just knéw TSLA was gonna break out, everything pointed in that direction. I was still holding like 2k+ in losing positions. Closed it all and bought one TSLA call - best decision.

author: yukinara
body:
While i do try to be funny there are still some kernel of truth here.

When you invest in stock you have no clue if a stock will perform as you want. So you look at the memes to see which one is popular and go from there. Popular stocks are the ones being pushed at the moment so there are other investors out there putting stakes into the companies too. Of course it's dumb to base off your whole investment strategy on that but it helps to start somewhere.

You can also invest in safe blue chip stocks that you see people use their products daily: amd, nvda, appl, msft, adbe, v, ma etc. Most of the time you wont go wrong because they're all solid.

author: ATXBikeRider
body:
No crystal ball here but IV crush is possible.  Also you are essentially wanting a run-up of another 4% which is a lot for AAPL in just 1 week.  It is definitely possible, but I mean if AAPL finished next week at 510 that would be considered amazing for the stock.  So that spread is risky!  If it was further out in expiration date that would be different.

With all of that said.  This shit could moon right after you sell or on Monday.  No one really knows!  

I have paper handed AAPL calls though that would have been $20 K in profit but they were over 6 weeks out when bought.  I also paper handed some ADBE calls that would be worth about $8 K right now.  But again they still had a month until expiration when I sold them.

 I definitely would be more nervous with just a week until expiration however since you are still a ways out of the money and it had already had a crazy run.  But I said the same think about TSLA multiple times haha.  AAPL has less meme power though.  Statistically it probably will not be in the money (about 40% chance of hitting 510 according to ToS).   If you got them cheap though they might be worth holding to see what happens. 

Either way this IS WSB and options so risk is necessary to get paid.

author: Amigo_del_Cartel
body:
My experience of college is that all decisions are made by tech illiterate boomers that can't find the fullscreen button.

They won't even use teams, Skype, Hangouts or whatever- it'll be something that nobody has ever heard of and it will only work if you have Adobe flash 3.0 and Windows XP installed.

Why? The key part is greed - they don't want people to be able to screen record because worse than dying of covid is people getting an education for free. They also don't give a fuck about your education because they k ow that once you're through the door and have paid your tuition, you're locked in for the next few years.

to;dr My college used something called mediasite. They are owned by Sonic Foundry $SOFO but my broker doesn't even list it. They have 120 followers on stocktwits... But it rocketed up in March.

author: ImmySnommis
body:
I'm interested in your pitch. If I may ask some questions...

When you say undervalued... Their P/E is over 250. GOOG/L, MSFT and AAPL are all in the 30s. Can you clarify?

What is their moat? Admittedly, I haven't used their services in years, but what differentiates them from similar services provided by GOOG, MSFT, ADBE and others?

Is there a case where you believe they are a takeover candidate?

Looking at their longer chart, after the initial pop of their IPO this stock has meandered slightly lower with few peaks and valleys. Is there something they announced that may generate new interest and/or revenue?

Please don't take this as knocking your idea, I'm always interested in opinions. I'm simply trying to understand.

author: Dr_Ne0n_Fleshbiscuit
body:
When I first started investing almost 30 years ago right out of college,  I put every other paycheck into mutual funds. After awhile I figured I could do at least as well as the meager returns they were earning, read the classic One Up On Wall Street, and decided to use my professional knowledge of the computer industry to guide my investments. This has worked incredibly well.

I was an early investor in AAPL, ADBE, AMZN, UI, TWLO, TSLA. And in companies that are gone due to acquisitions: Macromedia, Pixar. Others I rode up and sold off long ago when they lost their luster: IBM, Nokia. Many others.

My best results have always been from playing the long game buying companies with outstanding and unique offerings, when they were not well-known, hard to explain, unfairly maligned, or otherwise undervalued. They don't come along very often.

Investment funds can provide a decent return, by soothsaying financials, news, and trends, and you probably won't lose money in a well-managed fund.

However, if you have specialized knowledge, you can do incredibly well. It's a hobby that can lead to wealth, but if you're not interested in following the markets, decent is the safe bet.

A cloud storage consolidation service that has been extremely successful since '12. They partnered with Microsoft Azure in '18, and Google Cloud in '19. 

They have one of Microsoft's old CEOs, and a few high-profile customers such as Adobe and Capitol One.

 They raised almost $1.5B in VC, and are valued at around $20B I believe. Forbes rated them #2 in cloud computing in 2019; Linkedin ranked them as #1 startup. 

Shows a lot of promise as they already generate sales and are incorporated into some of the largest platforms out there.

author: _sillycibin_
body:
I feel like all the loads are blown now.  Seriously what's the next rocket/meme stock?  Nvidia, Tesla, Apple, Netflix, Adobe and Amazon are all played out I think for big gainz.  Same with tier 2 like Nio, Shopify, Mercadolibre, Roku, and Zoom.  I think Roku and Zoom are long term shit stocks anyway and don't want to be caught holding the bag/a retard without a chair when the music stops.  Tier 3 Fastly, Teladoc, some other cloud plays I'm blanking on but are solid long term but overheated short term I think.  They had profit taking recently.

Does Square or Paypal really have more left in the tank?  Facebook or Microsoft?

I think Ali Baba has lots of potential but China stocks don't get the same buzz, there's the trade war tension, and general hesitance about China stocks and accounting practices.  Walmart is a good stock long term but doesn't get the market hard.  Disney will shoot a wad when a vaccine is announced, but could have capital tied up for months.

Anyone have suggestions, someone killing it in the market, upcoming news/rumors acquisitions or new product?  $BABA with the ANT IPO in October will pop, but when?  Could have September runup or might wait until October to do it's thing.

author: cocaineflavoredwater
body:
AMD has upside but there trajectory in the last few months is definitely inflated.

Intel is still a good company and long term it will probably rise up because of them being the baseline for servers. They are still the gold standard in that space which is huge in any cloud based computing platform. But they might not grow as much with AMD looking better.

That being said a safer long term bet, as well as just a good indicator of the tech industry in general I'd look at the analog semiconductors such as ADI and TXN. Their stock maybe suffering from some overinflation as well, but the last five years both stocks have been generally moving upwards. With more Boomer ran industries such as Industrials/Automotive/and Medical industries are starting to invest heavily in "electrifying" their industries so analog semiconductors are now breaking into new markets at high rates. Also in the next couple years ADI will aquire Maxim, which is the combination of the second and third largest analog semiconductor companies. 

Also even the Intel and AMD chips need supporting circuitry which analog semiconductors still use.

Also because how sales work in that industry, a decrease in semiconductors typically precedes a decrease in the tech market. 

For short term gain I think semiconductors aren't the best play, these industries typically grow but can be hard to pin down in short term.

I'm waiting for a pullback, because I don't think we are out of the woods of a recession yet. And if it does I'm going to try to pick up stock and maybe some longer term options about ATM for a decent chance at profit because a yearly decline in semiconductors is pretty strange (INTC is still above a year ago even though they have done pretty bad as far as semis go in the last few months)

Source: I work in the Semiconductor industry.

author: poop_in_my_coffee
body: Analog Devices, Inc. (ADI) today announced its collaboration with Intel Corporation to create a flexible radio platform that addresses 5G network design challenges and will enable customers to scale their 5G networks more quickly and economically. The new radio platform combines the advanced technology of ADI's radio frequency (RF) transceivers with the high performance and low power of Intel Arria 10 Field Programmable Gate Arrays (FPGAs) giving developers a new set of design tools for more easily creating optimized 5G solutions.

body:

author: dwdsquared2
body:
**Events in the US Today (EDT):**

* 7:00am - MBA Mortgage Data \[1/3 Volatility\]
* 9:30am - Seevol Cushing Oil Storage Report \[2/3 Volatility\]
* 10:30am - Crude Oil Inventories \[3/3 Volatility\]
* **2:00pm - FOMC Meeting Minutes \[3/3 Volatility\]**
* The dollar headed for a sixth daily drop against its major peers while Treasuries rose. The moves precede the Federal Reserve releasing (today, 2:00pm) minutes of a  July 28-29 committee meeting that may give clues about inflation targeting.
* the S&P 500 hit its highest level ever, wiping out all the losses from the coronavirus sell-off. 
* In a positive signal for equities, House Speaker Nancy Pelosi suggested that Democrats might be willing to make more cuts to their stimulus proposal to seal a deal with Republicans and speed Covid-19 relief, then come back after the November elections with additional agenda items.
* President Donald Trump said he called off last weekend’s trade talks with China, raising questions about the future of a trade deal that is now the most stable point in an increasingly tense relationship.
   * “I canceled talks with China,” Trump said Tuesday in Yuma, Arizona. “I don’t want to talk to China right now.
* Crude oil eased after a report signaled surging U.S. gasoline stockpiles before OPEC and its allies meet to assess its supply agreement.
* Democrats officially nominated Joe Biden for president.

**Events in the World Today (EDT):**

* DAY - Hong Kong Typhoon Emergency - No Trading
* 2:00am - UK CPI (YoY-Jul) \[3/3 Volatility\]
   * PPI Input (MoM-Jul) \[2/3 Volatility\]
* 5:00am - Euro Zone CPI (YoY-Jul) \[3/3 Volatility\]
* 6:00am - Euro Zone EU Leaders Summit \[3/3 Volatility\]
* 8:30am - Canada Core CPI (MoM-Jul) \[3/3 Volatility\]
   * Canada Wholesale Sales (MoM-Jun) \[2/3 Volatility\]
* 10:00am - Joint Ministerial Monitoring Committee convened by OPEC+
* 9:30pm - China PBoC Loan Prime Rate \[3/3 Volatility\]
* OPEC oil producers and allies such as Russia, a grouping dubbed OPEC+, meets on Wednesday to review compliance with oil cuts meant to support oil prices amid the coronavirus pandemic.
   * OPEC+ is unlikely to change its output policy, which currently calls for reducing output by 7.7 million barrels per day (bpd) versus a record high 9.7 million bpd up until this month, according to OPEC+ sources.
   * They said the meeting instead would focus on compliance by countries such as Iraq, Nigeria and Kazakhstan.
* Asia stocks were mixed. Sentiment was dampened by lingering questions over the future of the U.S.-China trade pact after President Donald Trump said he called off last weekend’s trade talks. 
   * Adding to the uncertainty, the State Department is asking colleges and universities to divest from Chinese holdings in their endowments.
* British inflation jumped unexpectedly last month to its highest since March, as clothes shops did not hold their usual summer sales when they reopened after the coronavirus lockdown, but most economists expect it to fall again soon.

**Earnings Before Open:**

* Lowe's (6:00), Target (6:30), TJX, Analog Devices, Sharps, 

**Earnings After Close:**

* Nvidia (4:20), Synopsys, LBrands (4:05), Arcimoto, SQM, Nordson, GoHealth

[Earnings This Week](https://i.postimg.cc/PJY8b32m/er1.png)
